presentation.title: Coastal flood regulation in Madagascar
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from natural coastal protection in Madagascar (no flows)
presentation.description: Assessment of potential source, use and sinks related to ecosystem protection of coastal environments in Madagascar. This model does not include real-time ecosystem service flow analysis, as flows require more time to compute than is feasible for estimating on-the-fly.

page.name: Coastal flood regulation assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline, developed with financial support from the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre, describes aspects of coastal flood regulation in Madagascar. This island's coastal ecosystems include dunes, coral reefs, seagrass, and mangroves, all of which can play a role in dissipating wind and wave energy generated by coastal storms. Unlike more northerly nations bordering the Indian Ocean, Madagascar is rarely subject to earthquake-generated tsunami waves. However, eastern Madagascar is highly susceptible to tropical storms coming off the southwestern Indian Ocean. Its storms are relatively poorly studied, with limited infrastructure for measuring and modeling storm magnitude and impact versus other tropical storm prone regions in more developed parts of the world (Naeraa and Jury 1998).

The coastal storm protection models used here are intended as a proof-of-concept framework to spatially link: 1) storm wave sources; 2) ecosystem “sinks” that mitigate wave damage; and 3) social groups or assets that are susceptible to harm by coastal flooding. These models use historic storm track, wind speed, and atmospheric pressure data from tropical storms that occurred in a specified region of time. Tropical Storms Daisy, Geralda, and Litanne, three severe storms that made landfall near the port of Toamasina in 1994, are used in the first version of this model, based on availability of information from Naeraa and Jury (1998). The authors modeled aspects of these storms and their attendant storm surges, providing data for calibration of model results. Our model can easily be applied to other historical storm tracks in Madagascar or elsewhere and to simulated future storm tracks or other large wave events, such as tsunamis. These models can also be relatively easily generalized to other parts of the world, as they rely on global datasets for historical storms, coastal ecosystems capable of mitigating storm surges, and lives and property at risk of flood damage.
page.see-also:
Naeraa, M. and M.R. Jury. 1998. Tropical cyclone composite structure and impacts over Eastern Madagascar during January-March 1994. Meteorology and Atmospheric Physics 65: 43-53.
The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Model development: Ken Bagstad, Gary Johnson, Brian Voigt, Ferdinando Villa.
Funding and data support: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coastal lives at risk
page.title: Coastal lives at risk
page.description: This model considers populations that live in coastal flood zones as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Decile values of populations at risk of coastal flooding is thus identified as the use model and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model. In parts of the world where coastal flood zones have been mapped, we could overlay flood zones and population density to more accurately map lives at risk, rather than using the coarser resolution map presented here.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: CIESIN Columbia University
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coastal property at risk
page.title: Coastal property at risk
page.description:
This model considers economically valuable assets (structures and property) as the beneficiaries of coastal storm protection. Such data are available directly and there is no requirement for a probabilistic model.
Decile values of economic value at risk from coastal storms is published by CIESIN and is used directly.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: CIESIN Columbia University
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wind speed
page.title: Wind speed
page.description: Wind speed, obtained here from historical storm records, is proportional to the total potential damage inflicted by wind and waves and is used in the flow model to quantify the amount of damaging energy reaching coastal populations or assets or prevented from doing so by natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Seagrass
page.title: Seagrass presence
page.description: Seagrass beds, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mangrove presence
page.title: Mangrove presence
page.description: Mangroves, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Land and bathymetric slope
page.title: Land and bathymetric slope
page.description: Slope data, calculated both on land and for the ocean floor, are used to model the behavoir of waves as they move toward land. In the ocean, steep slopes cause more rapid wave buildup while over land, steep slopes cause more rapid dissipation of wave energy.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Storm surge
page.title: Storm surge
page.description: This map shows results of a Bayesian model estimating the height of a potential storm surge based on wind speed and atmospheric pressure for a historic storm, as well as the ocean depth at a given location. Greater wind speeds, lower atmospheric pressure, and shallower ocean depths are more likely to lead to greater storm surge heights. Height of the storm surge is in meters.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Artificial coastal protection
page.title: Artificial coastal protection
page.description: Seawalls and other engineered coastal protection can provide coastal flood mitigation, in combination with ecosystems or as a replacement of ecosystems in developed areas. Lacking data on coastal protection in Madagascar, we set artificial coastal protection is present near the port cities and absent elsewhere.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Coral reef quality
page.title: Coral reef quality
page.description:
Coral reefs, along with other vegetation and geomorphic features, are valuable in reducing wave energy that could otherwise inflict damage on coastal populations and property. When present, such features are used in the sink model to determine the total potential of the natural environment to mitigate damage inflicted to humans by storms or tsunamis.
We assume that healthy, unbleached coral reefs are better able to absorb wave energy than bleached reefs, based on coral reef presence and bleaching data from UNEP-WCMC and ReefBase.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Geomorphic protection
page.title: Geomorphic flood protection
page.description:
The amount of the storm-generated wave energy that reaches the coast depends on several factors, including the geomorphology on land and underwater. This map is a probabilistic assessment of the total protection provided by geomorphic features including sea floor depth, slope, terrestrial elevation, and the presence of dunes.
These data are used in the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Terrestrial vegetation
page.description:
The type of terrestrial vegetation encountered on the coast is an important determinant of how much wave and wind energy can be absorbed by the ecosystem before it reaches humans assets and settlements. We assume that forests and wetlands are most effective in mitigating wave energy, followed by shrubland and herbaceous ecosystems, with other vegetation types (urban and agriculture) providing minimal protection.
These data are used as input to the sink model, which estimates the total wave mitigation potential provided by natural features. The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Dunes
page.title: Dune presence
page.description: Dunes and bathymetric configuration account for the bulk of natural coastal protection in areas where mangroves and seagrass are scarce. These data are used as input to the sink model, which establishes the total protection potential determined by natural features. The sink model, The sink model, in turn, is used by the flow model to determine actual damage inflicted by storms and separate the influences of geomorphic wave mitigation (which would occur with or without ecosystems that provide wave mitigation) and the contribution of ecosystems in mitigating wave energy.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential coastal flood regulation
page.title: Potential coastal flood regulation
page.description:
This map is the probabilistic output of the *sink* model, which puts together all the potentially preventative features of the landscape into a single map. Each point of the map details the likely amount of wave energy that can be mitigated by such features.
The flow model uses this map to determine whether each point can deplete the energy coming from the storm front, thereby reducing the total amount of damage that reaches users.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wave source
page.title: Coastal wave source
page.description:
The height of coastal waves generated at a certain part of the seascape. This is the source of the potentially damaging wave created by storms or tsunamis before being intercepted by natural features along the coasts. It is estimated by processing historical storm records along recorded storm tracks, though hypothetical future storm tracks could also be modeled.
The source data are used as input to the flow model that computes how much wave energy is dissipated by ecosystems and how much protection benefit is accrued by humans in the process. These source data therefore do not account for flows.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Wave mitigation
page.title: Potential wave mitigation
page.description:
The *sink* model estimates the amount of service carrier (wave energy, estimated in meters) intercepted along the flow paths. For preventive services like coastal flood regulation, the sink model represents the actual benefit to humans, as it reduces the amount of a detrimental carrier (in this case, wave energy) capable of inflicting damage to the users.
This map of potential wave mitigation is produced from probabilistic models of all ecosystem-related factors likely to intercept wave energy alogn their damaging path towards the coast. As all "potential" ecosystem service maps, it is used as an input to the flow model and therefore does not account for flows.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Vulnerable groups
page.title: Potentially wave-vulnerable populations
page.description:
This map identifies all the potential users or beneficiaries of coastal flood regulation, and is estimated by determining the probability that people or economically valuable assets are located in flood zones.
This map, like all "potential" maps, is used as input and does not account for flows, but is used as an input to the flow models.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potentially damaging wave flow
page.description:
Potential flow maps represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow route of wave energy across the land and seascape in the absence of sinks. Therefore it computes the maximum damage that would happen if natural features did not intercept it, and provides a baseline that allows estimation of the actual value of those features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential waves
page.title: Source of potentially damaging waves
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This specific map represents what specific sources of waves are capable of harming people or damaging property when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Potential damage
page.title: Potential wave damage
page.description: This map shows people or property receiving damage when accounting for sources of wind or waves and their flow paths but not accounting for the action of sinks that reduce potential damage from wind or waves.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual waves
page.title: Actual wave flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map depicts the trajectories that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these trajectories that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these trajectories deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the trajectories show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this specific case, the density of actual flows represent the wave energy that impacts people or property, after accounting for wave routing due to winds, geophysics, and natural features that deplete their magnitude.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Flood source
page.title: Flood damaging wave source
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows the source of those waves that actually harm people or damage property when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual mitigation
page.title: Utilized wave mitigation
page.description: This map shows the sinks that actively reduce wave energy, providing the benefit of reduced flood or wind damage for people.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual damage
page.title: Wave damage received
page.description: This map shows actual damage received by people and property when accounting for source locations and strength of waves, the action of sinks, and flow paths.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Benign waves
page.title: Benign wave source
page.description:
The *unused source map" shows those areas of the source map whose values are irrelevant to the delivery of the service, because of the impossibility of reaching users given the relevant ecosystem services flow path. For provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. For preventive services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because the flow dynamics prevent the carrier from reaching any significant user.
This map shows wind or waves that do not have people or economically valuable assets lying in their path.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Unused protection
page.title: Unutilized wave mitigation
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows those sinks that actively reduce wind or waves, providing the benefit of reduced flood or wind damage for people.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Absorbed waves
page.title: Absorbed wave flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* depicts the trajectories that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these trajectories show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the trajectories show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows wave or wind energy that is absorbed by natural features prior to reaching human beneficiaries that could be damaged by wind or waves.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Mitigated waves
page.title: Mitigated wave source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows the portion of coastal wave energy whose damage potential is reduced by the action of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Total benefit
page.title: Wave mitigation benefits accrued
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows people or economically valuable assets who are spared from coastal flood or wind damage due to the flood or wind mitigating activity of natural features.
page.see-also: The coastal protection section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.
